awd_titl_txt: Menaquinone Physiochemical Properties Alter Energy Metabolism in Actinobacteria
awd_abstract_narration:
The Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division funds this award. Professors Debbie Crans and Dean Crick from Colorado State University investigate how a specific molecule plays a crucial part in the generation of energy from nutrients (metabolic energy) in microorganisms. The first step in production of metabolic energy is electron transport- where electrons are passed stepwise through a series of small molecules and proteins embedded in a membrane. One of these molecules is menaquinone. It has been known for a long time that menaquinone is involved in the electron transport steps, but how it participates in the process is still unknown. The structure and reactivity of the menaquinone molecule is investigated in this research. The critical electron transfer reaction is exquisitely sensitive to the structure of menaquinone. The basis for this sensitivity is examined by making small variations in the shape of the molecule and measuring the effects on the metabolic energy generation. These studies allow undergraduate students, graduate students and postdoctoral fellows to acquire specialized training in synthesis, analysis of molecular structures in solution and at the interfaces of artificial membranes, and microbiological methodology. The topic is presented to the public in suitable settings including outreach programs with K-12 students and other community groups.

The enzyme MenJ (Rv0561c) of Mycobacterium tuberculosis catalyzes the reductive conversion of menaquinone with nine isoprene units (MK-9) to menaquinone with nine isoprene units with the second isoprene unit saturated (MK-9(II-H2)). A subtle variation in the structure of MK-9(II-H2) results in surprisingly dramatic changes in survival and energy metabolism for the organism. How the conversion of a single bond to a double bond (MK-9(II-H2) to MK-9) could have such profound effects on the energy metabolism of mycobacteria is not understood. The current research project seeks to define the biological role of regiospecific saturation in MK derivatives. The physical properties of simple synthetic MK derivatives are investigated with the objective of elucidating the effects of saturation on solution structure, redox potentials, and molecular interactions at water/lipid interfaces. The results from these studies are used to develop an understanding for how these changes can affect MK's biological activities. The current hypothesis is that the shape of the molecule directs the biological responses.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Lipoquinones are molecules important to life and particularly to energy production, scientifically referred to as the electron transport chain.  As the name lipoquinone indicates they are lipids with a more water-soluble and reactive component referred to as the quinone part and a long side chain referred to as an isoprenyl sidechain.  Our project had to do with preparing water-soluble truncated lipoquinone derivatives and studying their properties. This is because little information was available on their structures and thus the space that they took up as they sit and act in the membranes, even though these compounds in the past had been used to characterize the type of bacteria or organism that they formed in.  In our project, we synthesized these compounds and studied them using spectroscopic techniques as well as characterized the biological properties that they have.

? We synthesized the compounds using known and new modified methods, because some of the methods reported did not work.  Our focus was on lipoquinone derivatives that had a sidechain with 1 to 3 isoprene groups. Some of the compounds had been made before and some of them not.  Some of the new compounds contained a part that had a higher H:C ratio than the basic lipoquinone derivative, that it they were partially or fully saturated.  This was important, because these structural details are important to the overall shape of the molecules, the way they work, and vary depending on the organism that makes them. 

? After we had prepared the truncated derivatives we discovered that these truncated derivatives are really important because they are a short and water-soluble version of the naturally occuring MK-derivatives.  The water-solubility means that we can study them and use them in many of the systems scientist work with.  We not only characterized the fundamental properties of these molecules, but also determined their structure.  Since these compounds are lipids, they like lipid-like environments, but we found that they had specific structures and not fat-globs as they were previously thought to be.  These compounds are generally represented in textbooks and publications as a straight chain, but our studies showed that they fold over themselves when they are located in the membrane.  This is important because they transfer between proteins in the membranes delivering electrons, so that the shape they take on is very important for recognition by the proteins they interact with.

? Finally, we began to study how these compounds worked in biological systems.  That is how they interacted with bacterial enzymes known to utilize lipoquinones in our in vitro assay. One of these enzymes was a new enzyme we discovered named MenJ.  MenJ is responsible for the addition of hydrogen (H2), also referred to as saturation or hydrogenation of the second isoprene unit of mycobacterial menaquinone, which contains nine isoprene units.  The synthesized compounds were also tested and most were found to be substrates for MenJ depending on their structure.

 


Last Modified: 01/12/2022
Modified by: Debbie C Crans

por.por_txt_cntn:
Lipoquinones are molecules important to life and particularly to energy production, scientifically referred to as the electron transport chain.  As the name lipoquinone indicates they are lipids with a more water-soluble and reactive component referred to as the quinone part and a long side chain referred to as an isoprenyl sidechain.  Our project had to do with preparing water-soluble truncated lipoquinone derivatives and studying their properties. This is because little information was available on their structures and thus the space that they took up as they sit and act in the membranes, even though these compounds in the past had been used to characterize the type of bacteria or organism that they formed in.  In our project, we synthesized these compounds and studied them using spectroscopic techniques as well as characterized the biological properties that they have.

? We synthesized the compounds using known and new modified methods, because some of the methods reported did not work.  Our focus was on lipoquinone derivatives that had a sidechain with 1 to 3 isoprene groups. Some of the compounds had been made before and some of them not.  Some of the new compounds contained a part that had a higher H:C ratio than the basic lipoquinone derivative, that it they were partially or fully saturated.  This was important, because these structural details are important to the overall shape of the molecules, the way they work, and vary depending on the organism that makes them. 

? After we had prepared the truncated derivatives we discovered that these truncated derivatives are really important because they are a short and water-soluble version of the naturally occuring MK-derivatives.  The water-solubility means that we can study them and use them in many of the systems scientist work with.  We not only characterized the fundamental properties of these molecules, but also determined their structure.  Since these compounds are lipids, they like lipid-like environments, but we found that they had specific structures and not fat-globs as they were previously thought to be.  These compounds are generally represented in textbooks and publications as a straight chain, but our studies showed that they fold over themselves when they are located in the membrane.  This is important because they transfer between proteins in the membranes delivering electrons, so that the shape they take on is very important for recognition by the proteins they interact with.

? Finally, we began to study how these compounds worked in biological systems.  That is how they interacted with bacterial enzymes known to utilize lipoquinones in our in vitro assay. One of these enzymes was a new enzyme we discovered named MenJ.  MenJ is responsible for the addition of hydrogen (H2), also referred to as saturation or hydrogenation of the second isoprene unit of mycobacterial menaquinone, which contains nine isoprene units.  The synthesized compounds were also tested and most were found to be substrates for MenJ depending on their structure.
